Tavatron continued to stare skyward, flicking an ear in agreement with 
Dinobot. Life was precious, and something one didn�t really appreciate until 
they no longer had it. She planned on living a long time, however, and 
wasn�t about to dwell on what was yet to be.  As the sky became shrouded in 
fog Tavatron resettled herself so that her tail was no longer crumpled in a 
very uncomfortable position beneath her. Slag it, that hurt. The one bad 
thing about having a tail was the inability to find a comfortable position 
when one was on their back. Well, it had always been a problem for her.

Dinobot had remained quiet for a while now, something she had grown used to. 
Still, something about his silence troubled the femme �bot. It was just a 
feeling, one that wouldn�t stop nagging at her circuits. It figured that 
despite her enjoyment of her current situation SOMETHING would start 
bothering her. It seemed she never got any peace. It was enough to make a 
�bot go mad. She had grown accustomed to the constant upheavals in her life, 
so this was nothing new.

Tavatron jumped at the sound of Dinobot�s voice. Who was he yelling at? She 
followed his gaze, trying to pinpoint some far off threat, but she found 
nothing. Was there something she had missed? Was someone following them? 
Suddenly she too was on her feet, the fact that they were quite a ways from 
the ground didn�t sink in until she had already drawn her sword and scanned 
the area as best she could. She then turned to face Dinobot, her sword 
lowering until the tip nearly touched Necromancer�s back. He was yelling at 
the stars? Tavatron raised a questioning eye-ridge as she swiveled her ears 
forward, her expression one of mild curiosity and intense confusion. This 
was completely unlike him. Had he gone mad from loss of fluid?

From what she could tell this had something to do with his past, a thing he 
had never really talked about with her. It was understandable, even she 
didn�t like talking about what had been when there was still so much that 
could be. Still, perhaps there was more to this than she thought. Dinobot 
really did look upset. She would make it a point to ask him about it later, 
when they were safely on the ground and he was repaired. His current state 
couldn�t be helping matters.

Tavatron nearly jumped as the massive dragon they were riding spoke. They 
were landing?! She could worry about Dinobot later, right now she had to sit 
down or else�

No sooner had Tavatron thought of the possibility of falling did Necromancer 
land. The force of the landing threw her from the Dragon�s back, and left 
her sprawled in the dirt a few feet from him. With a shake of her head and a 
growl of annoyance Tavatron got up and sheathed her sword. They were here, 
and Dinobot was still breathing. She thanked Necromancer for the ride before 
turning in Dinobot�s direction:

"Well, are you coming?"

She had meant what she said in a very light-hearted sense. He no doubt had 
seen her fall, so she was trying to make the best of an embarrassing 
situation.
